title: About
text:
About :
I am a medical doctor from Ghana and an MPH candidate at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. My long-term ambition is to become a **pediatric oncologist**, improving outcomes for children with cancer through research and equitable care delivery. As part of my MPH journey, I‚Äôm taking advanced coursework in ** statistical programimg paradigms and workflows** and building strong **R** skills for data analysis, which I see as essential for modern, precision-medicine research.
Research interests
- Pediatric hematologic cancers:novel genetic sequencing approaches and translational pipelines.
- Precision medicine & big data:reproducible analytics, rigorous inference, and clinically meaningful endpoints. ¬†
- Equity: ensuring innovations reach children in low-resource settings.
Technical toolbox
- R (tidyverse, visualization, data wrangling) ¬†
- Reproducible workflows (Quarto, literate programming) ¬†
- Intro methods for genomics/biostatistics; growing skills in modeling and data engineering






NoteConnect with me




     

Let‚Äôs connect! I‚Äôm always open to collaborations, mentorship, and new ideas.

title: Home
text:
I‚Äôm a physician from Ghana and an MPH candidate at Johns Hopkins focusing on health policy and digital health. I‚Äôm passionate about equity-centered, data-driven public health.

Example analysis: a reproducible mini-analysis in R







Tip



Fun fact:
**Inspiration.** I often revisit Steve Jobs‚Äô 2005 Stanford commencement [address] that keeps me grounded and bold.

title: Example analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
#| include: false 

library(tidyverse) 

library(palmerpenguins) 

library(janitor)

 library(lubridate) 

library(gt) 

theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 13))
peng <- penguins |>
  janitor::clean_names() |>                                 # clean_names()  ‚Äî janitor
  tidyr::drop_na(species, island, sex, body_mass_g,
                 bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm) |>          # drop_na()     ‚Äî tidyr
  dplyr::mutate(
    body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000,                      # mutate()      ‚Äî dplyr
    species = forcats::fct_reorder(species, body_mass_kg, .fun = median)
  ) |>
  dplyr::select(species, island, sex, bill_length_mm,
                bill_depth_mm, body_mass_kg) |>             # select()      ‚Äî dplyr
  dplyr::arrange(species, island)                           # arrange()     ‚Äî dplyr

long_bills <- peng |>
  tidyr::pivot_longer(                                      # pivot_longer()‚Äî tidyr
    c(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm),
    names_to = "bill_metric",
    values_to = "bill_value"
  )

title: Example analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
Summary
The dataset shows clear morphological separation among species, with Gentoo typically heavier and with longer bills than Adelie and Chinstrap. Faceting by island suggests context matters: distributions shift by location, hinting at ecological or sampling differences. Sex also contributes to variance in mass, consistent with mild sexual dimorphism. Together, these patterns are easy to communicate with tidy wrangling and layered graphics.

title: Example analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
Function checklist

dplyr: mutate, select, arrange, group_by, summarise, n
tidyr: drop_na, pivot_longer
ggplot2: geom_point, geom_smooth, geom_boxplot, geom_histogram, facet_wrap, plus labs, theme

title: Example analysis: Palmer Penguins
text:
Citations
We used palmerpenguins [@horst2020palmerpenguins], tidy data manipulation [@wickham2014dplyr], and grammar of graphics [@wickham2016ggplot2].
